Men of War Assault Squad 2 is the 2005 Toyota Camry of WWII Real Time Strategy games. Yes, the body shows a bit of rust and the occasional knock to remind you that it's mortal. But as newer, sleeker models and competitors come and go with their own problems, MoWAS 2 stays. For the record I want to say I started playing this game in 2021-2022, so I'm not biased by nostalgia going back to the Windows 7 days.

The game is janky (though pretty damn good for a game that's a decade old). It looks old, even for it's time. The engine sometimes has issues, but man the level of detail. Most of the environment is destructible, and depending on what kind of weapons used in a match a city can basically get flattened in the crossfire. Different parts of tanks will get damaged or break without there being a whole health bar (I still love you C&C) and you can even control tanks/infantry in case the AI decides to take a dump on you. It's been difficult getting into other RTS games because THIS one has so much to offer.

I thoroughly recommend the "World at War" addon for MoWAS2. Get your RTS buddies playing the base game and then going onto the addon; it feels like a DLC that is worth your time if not money. There's ALOT of WWII RTS games out there, but the level of detail kept me coming back to this gem. 

Find friends to buy this game for. 

Search for groups online to play this game with. 

Even if you're not a WWII enthusiast, there's also Star Wars mods out there that are also fantastic.

It may look dated, but it is extremely fun with granular levels of command - to the extent you can even take direct control of individual soldiers, vehicles and tanks.

It also has mods for pretty much any conflict you could think of (there's even Revolutionary War and Star Wars mods). The Italians are conspicuously absent from the list of Axis powers but there are no doubt countless mods for them too.

Overview:
 A little short and sweet summary for this game is this game is very fun but incredibly unbalanced in some modes recommend having a friend or two for some campaign and skirmish fun.

The Actual Review:

 There's a lot of good in this game and i think if they ever made a true successor to this with some better unit control and better UI/AI it could be one of my favorites in the RTS genre.  But after playing a good 30 hours (some on my friends pc) I can say there is some minor hiccups that take away from it.  First is the positives which is unit variety and semi realism in unit/vehicle tactics, The variety added with a WW2 game was pretty refreshing. I'm so used to seeing re-skinned tanks that work nay the same as the enemies that jumping into this one i had to play around a bit to see what unit actual were good for. Sure they have similar one to one's like trucks and soldiers for the most part, but they also have a good list of unique country specific ones as well which added to the replay value. Units also not being a giant health bar was nice too because idk about other people but ive grown tired of the health bar sponges from games like the Warhammer series. Soldiers are the only exception in this game but it doesn't feel like it as soldiers die in three to four good hits. And vehicles work as they should requiring either a well thrown Molotov into the top of a troop carrier or some AP to take the buggers down.

 The downsides of this game though can shine through sometimes, first off is the balancing of the Skirmish mode. It's the multiplayer mode pretty much that has a few game-modes that i wont go into this review, But the balance is way off. Every match i've played against the AI and some players has devolved into tank/ artillery spam. It's bad enough trying to play the game well juggling roughly a hundred men and a handful a vehicles but add the brain dead AI in and all the sudden it's world of tanks lite. Dozens of fury's bulldozing over the hill against your well placed militia as they get mowed down by the ten's of dozen's might be tactical but ruins the idea of a well balanced roster. Unit caps would fix this and there might be a option but the UI is so bad it's hard to find the start button to begin with. 

 Last thing ill add is that the campaign's although mostly easy are a nice touch especially being coop friendly. All and all id recommend this game too any hardcore RTS fan as i believe it to be the best out there. But be ready to tweak the Skirmish mode settings and hopefully drag a few bro's to play with you. A solid 8/10 for me just needs a better UI and unit caps for me.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is what happens when someone takes a WWII RTS and says:
‚ÄúCool‚Ä¶ now let‚Äôs give you full control of every single bullet.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt Company of Heroes-style ‚Äúmacro with some cover‚Äù. This is hyper-detailed, squad-level warfare where you can:

Manually loot corpses for ammo and grenades

Drag AT guns into position by hand

Take direct control of a single soldier or tank and aim every shot yourself

Turn a wrecked street into a kill zone with one well-placed MG and a couple of sandbags

When it clicks, the game is pure tactical bliss.
You set up overlapping fields of fire, hide infantry behind a stone wall, ambush a tank with a single brave sapper, and watch entire enemy pushes evaporate because your plan actually worked.

The real strengths:

Skirmish & co-op: This is where AS2 shines. Cooperative skirmishes against the AI are ridiculously fun ‚Äì desperate, messy, cinematic in that unscripted way.

Direct control: Being able to jump into a tank, manually aim HE rounds at infantry, then switch to AP and snipe enemy armor never gets old.

Physics & detail: Explosions matter, cover gets shredded, tanks lose tracks, and a single well-placed shell can change everything.

But it‚Äôs also absolutely not a casual game.

The downsides:

The UI and learning curve are harsh. There‚Äôs a lot of micro, a lot of hotkeys, and the game explains almost nothing.

Some missions and skirmishes can feel like meat grinders ‚Äì the AI just keeps coming, and if your lines collapse, they really collapse.

The progression/unlocks can feel grindy if you just want to jump in and play with all the toys.

In short:

If you want a relaxed RTS, Assault Squad 2 will probably just stress you out.
But if you enjoy painfully detailed tactics, improvising under pressure, and turning hopeless situations into heroic last stands through clever play and a few stolen Panzerfausts ‚Äì this is one of the best WWII sandboxes out there.

It‚Äôs not pretty in a modern AAA sense, but the stories it generates on the battlefield? Those are unforgettable.

Mow:AS2, on it's own, is enjoyable when:

- you're willing to keep up with some 20 year old control scheme bullshit
- have friends to play with

Still, it'd be better to buy Gates of Hell: Ostfront instead, unless your friends already have this. I can not recommend this game as the first option in the year 2025

Bottom line is don't bother with this unless it goes on sale for less than $10.

Mow:AS2, on it's own, is enjoyable when:

- you're willing to keep up with some 20 year old control scheme bullshit
- have friends to play with
- are potentially a masochist, sadist or sadomasochist.

The game does not care for your feelings, nor is it a good introduction to the genre (nor the series), but it's a very unique kind of fun to destroy your opponent's super weapon or game winning move with partisans, right after burning yourself with a flamethrower and followed immediately by an epic tank battle.

Still, it'd be better to buy Gates of Hell: Ostfront instead, unless your friends already have this. I can not recommend this game as the first option in the year 2025
